After five years of such practice, one may ascend to the Nine Heavens upon clouds, where one’s name is inscribed in the Register of Immortals. Even one’s seven generations of ancestors will receive blessings and joy, escaping the Three Wretched Paths to dwell in the Southern Palace of Immortals.

The Supreme Prime Lord of the Southern Culmen states: Those who study in the world know only to seek in the morning and expect results by evening, to utter a single vow and hope for the Dao’s descent, to recite spells and await response—yet they do not understand that ascending the heights of Mount Qi begins with the first step on the mountain’s base, that a thousand-foot tree grows from the tiniest sprout. The Dao is lofty and truly wondrous; how could one set foot and immediately climb the cloud ladder?

Even the Thearch-Lord, who governs the true qi by mandate, must still kindle a bright lamp to commune with the Dao. How much more should the Five Vows be cherished as blessings, for they naturally encompass all things. The path of seeking immortality must begin with vows, followed by the pursuit of those vows, so that resonance may summon the numinous. The greatness of the Five Vows lies in their boundless inclusivity—no blessing is left unbestowed, no joy left unshared, no goodness left unpurified. If one can focus the heart sincerely upon the vows, there will be no lack of response. Those of later generations who hold such sentiments should take heed and reflect deeply.

The Most Exalted Azure Lad of the Upper Prime states: In my past studies, I traversed seven hundred years, scaling perilous peaks, crossing from east to west, journeying through south and north, wandering the Central Plains. I studied under thirty-two masters and received over three hundred teachings, yet I had not ascended to the Golden Gates to receive from the Sage Lord the sacred scriptures of purple texts, the Dao of ingesting the yellow essence of sun and moon to restrain the hun and po, of binding the radiant brilliance of the Nine Perfected and Eight Ways, of dissolving form and concealing transformation, of traversing the purple passage of flaming light, of wielding the flowing gold and fire bells, of exhaling and inhaling flying auroras, of soaring through the void and treading the clouds, of pacing the Seven Primordial Treasures. The Sage Lord, by the shifting of the Seven Stars—a treasure of the Supreme Thearch—swore an oath and transmitted these teachings, enabling me to sever the six palaces of death and seal the northeastern ghostly gate. Only then did my name ascend to the Celestial Pass, where my body was shifted, allowing me to ascend the Three Primes and serve in office. Thus, I attained the rank of Most Exalted Minister, overseeing the host of immortals. The Seven Stars blazed and fell from the heavens, revolving the essence of the Nine Origins. Above, I rode the qi of the Three Primes; below, I governed the names of the Six Heavens. Birth and death, separation and union—none occur apart from the Seven Stars. For when the Dipper’s influence falls upon a person, they die; when it shifts away, they live. Thus, the Seven Stars are the ministers of heaven, the Celestial Pass the treasury of life’s renewal.

If one studies without severing the gate of death beneath the Northern Dipper or shifting the eye of life at the Southern Pass, how can life be preserved? The Supreme Emperor entrusted this scripture to the chambers of the Six Directions, commanding the Jade Maiden of the Western Flower and the Golden Lad of the Golden Dawn—three hundred in all—to guard the sacred text. Later, it was transmitted to the assembled perfected and emerged from the famous mountains. The Lord of the Western City later discovered this text within the stone chamber of Wangwu Mountain. After retiring to purify himself for three months, he presented his pledge and journeyed to the mountain to receive and peruse it. Through the practice of the Seven Stars’ shifting, he attained the rank of Perfected. Since then, no one without a jade name or immortal destiny has been able to encounter this Dao. For those who possess this scripture, the Six Palaces of Fengdu will record their names and shift them to the Southern Pass—how much more so for those who cultivate its practice?

The Lord of the Western City states: This original text comprised three scrolls—*The Celestial Pass* and *The Celestial Charts*—which do not circulate in the world. The Southern Marchmount Lady received only one scroll, *The Seven Stars’ Shifting*. Here ends *The Upper Clarity Scripture of the Three Charts of the Celestial Pass*.
